I have reviewed more than 1000 of resumes and here's what actually makes a good resume!
🚀 Your Resume is Getting Rejected Before a Human Even Sees It - Here’s Why!
Did you know? 75% of resumes never reach a recruiter’s eyes. They get filtered out by something scarier than your last job interview - the ATS (Applicant Tracking System).
Most people make basic mistakes that turn their resumes into invisible job applications. If your resume isn’t getting you interviews, you might be making these career-killing mistakes ⬇️
🔴 Fancy fonts & excessive formatting – ATS prefers simplicity. Stick to Arial, Calibri, or Times New Roman. Avoid tables, text boxes, or graphics.
🔴 PDF or Word? – Some ATS systems struggle with docx file. When in doubt, submit a pdf file.
🔴 Overly creative job titles – 'Chief Happiness Officer' sounds fun, but ATS won’t recognize it. Use industry-standard titles.
🔴 Lack of keywords – ATS looks for specific skills from the job description. If you’re applying for a Data Analyst role but your resume doesn’t mention ‘SQL’ or ‘Tableau,’ say goodbye to that job. Use keywords smartly!
🔴 Objective Statements (Nobody Cares 😅) – Replace that ‘Looking for an opportunity to grow’ fluff with a powerful summary of your achievements.
🔴 Too much personal info – The ATS doesn’t care about your age, gender, or full address. Keep it professional.
🔴 Your work experience is missing impact – Don’t just list responsibilities. Instead of ‘Handled social media’, write ‘Increased social media engagement by 60% in 3 months.’
🔴 Unnecessary sections – Hobbies, declarations, personal statements? Nobody cares. Keep it clean & professional.
🔴 Your resume is full of buzzwords – ‘Hardworking, passionate, dedicated team player’ doesn’t prove anything. Show, don’t tell!
So, how do you make your resume ATS-friendly & job-winning?
✅ Use bullet points – Easier to scan, both for ATS & humans. (12-35 words)
✅ Mirror the job description – Take important skills/keywords from the job post & weave them into your resume.
✅ Quantify achievements – ‘Increased sales by 30%’ is stronger than ‘Handled sales.’
✅ Use standard section headings – Stick to ‘Work Experience’ instead of ‘Journey So Far.’
✅ File name matters – Instead of ‘Resume_Final_2(1).pdf,’ use ‘John_Doe_DataAnalyst_Resume.pdf’
✔ Keep it simple & professional – No colors, images, charts, or fancy designs. The ATS won’t read them.
✔ Add relevant certifications & skills – ATS ranks resumes higher if they include industry-specific skills.
A good resume gets you an interview. 
A bad one? Doesn’t even get past the robot :)
All the best!

You don’t have to have it all figured out. 
Not today. Not tomorrow. Not ever, actually.
Some days, waking up and trying again is more than enough. 
Some days, smiling through the chaos is the real strength. 
And some days, just sitting in silence with yourself… 
is a conversation with God.
The world may measure success in numbers and noise -
But your soul only cares about peace.
So breathe. 
Drink your chai. 
Call your mom. 
Look at the sky for no reason. 
And remind yourself:
You are not behind. 
You are not broken. 
You are just growing in ways that can't be seen yet.
The universe isn’t in a rush. 
And neither should you be.
Something beautiful is blooming inside you -
even if no one claps yet. 
Even if it’s quiet. 
Even if it’s slow.
You are exactly where you're meant to be.

I once read:
'If you want to feel rich, just count all the things you have that money can’t buy.'
And today, I did.
A friend who checks on me randomly.
Parents who still treat me like a kid (even when I mess up).
A sibling who’ll roast me and defend me in the same breath.
A stranger who smiled at me today.
That one teacher who still remembers me.
The peace I feel after a long walk.
The excitement of starting something new.
A playlist that never fails me.
Laughter over inside jokes.
And my own self - growing slowly, but growing.
A warm cup of chai or coffee on a rainy day
Watching the sunset in silence
That one song that feels like a hug
Unexpected compliments from unexpected people
Long conversations that feel like 5 minutes
Old photos that make me smile
That one person who always believes in me
The joy of helping someone without expecting anything back.
If you smiled reading any of these,
you’re doing better than you think.
Not everything is perfect.
But not everything needs to be.
It’s a good life.
Let’s not forget that.

Your 9 to 5 is not your identity.
Your job title is not your personality.
And your LinkedIn headline is not your worth.
We live in a world where:
Success is measured in CTC
Growth is mistaken for promotions
And burnout is glorified as 'dedication'
Leaving work on time is seen as 'lack of passion'
Taking a break is considered 'falling behind'
Mental health is discussed only on World Mental Health Day
Loyalty is expected, but never reciprocated
And people clap louder for your job title than your character.
14-hour shifts are called 'hustle culture'
Saying 'no' makes you the villain
Vacations need to be justified
Crying in the restroom is normalised
Promotions are delayed but expectations aren’t
Constant availability is called being 'proactive'
You're judged more for your LinkedIn gap than your pain
And layoffs are announced in the name of 'restructuring'
Somewhere, we forgot that:
Peace is success
Boundaries are healthy
And life is much more than your job title
Taking care of your mental health is also ambition.
Spending time with family is also growth.
Being kind is also a flex.
Work hard. Chase dreams.
But don’t forget to live in the process.
If you're tired of pretending everything's perfect,
this post is for you.

I saw many videos and visuals of the attack in Kashmir but this video was the worst for me!
Imagine being a woman who just lost her husband and then she sees a person with a gun and gets scared that they're coming for her child.
The Indian Army officer had to tell her multiple times that they're here to help them and will not kill her child.
This feels so helpless!
I am shook, cannot comprehend the fear.
'Mere bache ko kuch matt karna' - she repeated that more than 3 times.
This is beyond sad and disturbing!
No one should live with this amount of fear.
This is not a scene from a war zone.
This is someone’s home.
This is Kashmir - yesterday.

Not even 100 days ago, I was lying on a hospital bed…
Tears in my eyes.
Fear in my chest.
And a loud silence in my mind.
I wasn’t recovering from surgery.
I was recovering from something harder to explain - anxiety attacks and depression.
No visible scars. But inside, I was shattered.
I was drowning in emotions I didn’t have names for.
Some days I couldn’t get out of bed.
Some days I avoided calls just because I couldn’t fake a smile.
Some days I genuinely thought… maybe this pain will never leave me.
But the most painful part?
Feeling like I was too much for this world.
Too emotional. Too silent. Too sensitive. Too “difficult.”
And yet - here I am today.
Travelling. Breathing. Laughing.
This is my second trip in years.
I took my first one in April - after what felt like forever.
And now, I’m slowly finding myself again.
Healing hasn’t been magical. It’s been messy.
I still get triggered. I still get anxious.
But now, I know how to hold my own hand when I fall.
And I owe a huge part of that to Mahadev and spirituality.
In moments of darkness, it was faith that kept me going.
The belief that this pain, too, had a purpose.
That I was being broken only to be rebuilt.
The silence of prayer.
The strength of surrender.
The reminder that I’m never truly alone.
To anyone out there silently struggling with anxiety or depression:
You are not alone.
You don’t have to rush your healing.
You don’t need to justify your sadness.
You are allowed to take time, to rest, to begin again.And to those who stood by me, even when I didn’t know how to ask for help -
Thank you. Your kindness saved me in ways words never can.
Please, be kind. Always.
Someone out there is fighting battles you cannot see.
This post is not about a trip -
It’s about courage.
It’s about survival.
It’s about hope.
With folded hands,
Thank you, Mahadev.
Thank you, life.
I’m coming back. One breath at a time.
Jo toot kar bikhar jaaye,
Wahi toh sach mein sanwarti hai.
With gratitude,
Muskan

She was on a ventilator.
She couldn’t speak.
She couldn’t move.
She couldn’t even scream.
And that’s when he raped her.
Right there, in the ICU.
While two nurses stood and watched.
They did nothing.
This happened at one of India’s top hospitals – Medanta, Gurugram.
A place where people go to save lives.
Not to lose their dignity.
This is not just a news headline.
This is a terrifying reality for women in India.
Where even in a hospital bed, with machines keeping you alive,
You are not safe.
We talk about women empowerment.
We celebrate Women’s Day.
But what about women’s safety?
What about basic human decency?
This is not just the failure of one person.
This is the failure of an entire system.
If two nurses can watch a woman being raped and do nothing -
then who's sicker: the rapist, or the system?
Speak up. Share. Shout.
Let her voice be heard.
Because if we stay silent today,
Tomorrow it could be someone we know.
Someone you love.
Someone too helpless to scream.
You don’t need to be her to fight for her. You just need to be human.

You don’t need a million followers to be impactful.
You just need to be real.
In a world that’s obsessed with being *loud*, I hope you find the courage to be *true*.
Because someone is watching you heal and getting inspired to not give up. 
Someone is learning from your calm, your patience, your kindness. 
Someone is choosing peace over chaos because of the way you respond to things. 
Someone is learning to believe in themselves again because you chose to rise.
You’re doing more than you think. 
You’re inspiring people you don’t even know.
So if you ever feel like you’re behind or not doing enough -
remember, growth is not always loud. 
Sometimes, it’s silent. 
Sometimes, it’s painful. 
And most of the time, it’s invisible.
But it’s happening. 
And that’s enough.
Keep going. 
You’re making a difference just by being *you*.

Toxic workplaces are so weird.
I had an opportunity to work at so many internships and companies.
Some were toxic,
Imagine fighting a 40-50 year old guy just because of office politics.
Chaache ki umar ki ho aap mere, kya ladu main aapse?
Weird.
Zameen ki ladai laddte hai chaache se, abb aap se office mein bhi ladu?
Shakuni Mama.

We often underestimate the power of small wins. Sometimes, it's not about huge accomplishments, but about getting through a tough day, making a small improvement, or pushing past a challenge. These small steps add up over time. Don't wait for the big breakthrough to celebrate your progress. Every step forward matters.

It’s easy to get caught up in the rat race and constantly compare yourself to others. But true success comes when you focus on your own growth and celebrate your unique journey. Stay in your lane, and work on becoming the best version of yourself. The rest will follow.

Mentorship is one of the most valuable resources in your career. A mentor doesn’t just share advice—they help you see things from a new perspective and push you to challenge your limits. If you have a mentor, appreciate them. If you don’t, seek one out. Growth happens faster when you have someone guiding you along the way.

Work-life balance isn’t a myth, but it requires boundaries and discipline. It's not about working less, but about working smarter and making time for what truly matters. Your career can thrive without sacrificing your personal life. It’s all about finding that balance that works for you.
